proposals.reasoning: Table consensus heavily favored anchoring around Henry plus me (Alice) as a low-drama, low-risk core. For the third slot, multiple players (Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry, Iris) explicitly mentioned Iris as a good flexible option who isn’t part of the ‘usual suspects’ trio, which keeps early trust from over-concentrating on the same people. This team aligns with the majority’s comfort (Henry+Alice) while adding a quieter, less auto-trusted player (Iris) to generate useful alignment information from the mission result without feeling like an engineered ‘too safe’ stack.

votes.comment: Henry + me was broad consensus and Iris is a reasonable, non-controversial third; good enough info-gathering team for Quest 1.
This matches the Henry+Alice+Iris structure I already supported and I don’t want to disrupt the strong early consensus on this low-drama opener.
Solid low-drama opener around Henry/Alice; no strong reasons to distrust Iris yet and we need early info.
Team matches broad table consensus and I’m fine with a low-drama, info-generating first mission.
Solid consensus Henry+Alice core with Iris as a flexible third; nothing alignment-breaking early, so we should take the info from this Mission 1 team.
No obvious red flags and it matches broad table consensus around Henry+Alice with a flexible third; fine as a low-risk opener.
Consensus-backed, I’m not on it, and rejecting a broadly safe first mission would look unnecessarily suspicious.
I’m on it with a broadly trusted core and a reasonable third; good info and low risk for M1.
Henry+Alice is a widely trusted core and adding me gives useful early info without looking engineered; nothing stands out as risky enough to reject on Mission 1.

discussion.content: Early on I’d like to start with a low-drama, low-risk group, so I’m inclined to trust someone like Bob or Henry for the first mission based on how consistently solid they’ve been in past games. I’m happy to be on it too, but I mostly want at least one of those “steady” players included.

I appreciate the vote of confidence, but I don’t think I *have* to be on the first team—Henry feels like a solid anchor, and I’d be happy with something like Henry + Alice + one of Eve/Iris so we get a mix of steady and lower-profile players to start.

I like anchoring around Henry too, but I’d also feel better if we included either Frank or Grace on the first team since they’ve both played pretty reliably in past games. Something like Henry + Alice + Frank/Grace seems like a solid, low-drama opener.

Henry as an anchor feels pretty universally acceptable, and I’d lean Henry + Alice + Grace to start, since that gives us two “steady” players plus someone who’s usually clear in their reasoning so we have something to read from the outcome.

I’m fine anchoring around Henry as well, but I’d slightly prefer a mix that isn’t just the “usual suspects,” like Henry + Alice + one of Eve/Iris/Frank so we’re not putting all our early trust in the same core trio.

Henry + Alice as a core feels fine to me, but I’d rather see the third spot go to someone like Iris, Frank, or Eve than lock in Grace this early. That keeps us flexible while still giving a pretty readable first mission.
I’m fine with the Henry + Alice core, but I don’t think I need to be auto-included here—I'd rather see something like Henry + Alice + Iris/Eve and use the result to start building real reads.

If everyone’s comfortable using me as an anchor, I’d lean Henry + Alice + Iris for Mission 1 so we’ve got one “steady” pair plus a quieter player who’ll give us some info without stacking all the usual suspects together.

I’m good with Henry + Alice as a core, and I don’t mind being the third—if people prefer to keep me off for now though, I’d still want Henry on and would probably swap in someone like Eve rather than auto-locking Grace this early.

proposals.reasoning: This team follows the widely supported 'keep two from Mission 1 and add two new' approach, preserving the proven Alice–Henry core while expanding information by adding me (Bob) and Diana. Alice and Henry were both on the clean first mission, which the table generally wants to partially preserve, and multiple players (Alice, Charlie, Diana, Grace, Henry) have either directly proposed or expressed comfort with this exact or near-identical lineup. This makes the team both socially acceptable and information-rich: if it passes and succeeds, we strengthen trust in Alice and Henry and get good signals on Bob/Diana; if it fails, we immediately narrow suspicion to the new additions while still having clear data anchored to the known clean team structure from Mission 1.

votes.comment: Keeps the clean Alice–Henry core while testing two new players; if it fails we tightly localize suspicion to Bob/Diana, so it’s both reasonable and informative.
Gives us more info by testing two new players while keeping the trusted Alice–Henry core from Mission 1.
Solid early info team: keeps two from the clean Mission 1 and tests two new players; no strong red flags yet so I want the data.
I like keeping two from the clean Mission 1 and adding two new players for more information, and this lineup fits that plan well.
Team follows the agreed keep-two-add-two plan with the trusted Alice–Henry core; good info gain and no strong reason yet to distrust Bob or Diana.
I don’t love auto‑locking Bob this early; I’d rather see two from Mission 1 plus two from Charlie/Diana/Eve/Iris instead of centering this on Bob.
Both my evil teammates are on it with two trusted cores, so it’s a great chance to sabotage while looking like a standard info-gathering team.
Keeps the Alice–Henry core from a clean Mission 1 and tests two new players; good early info-gathering team with no strong red flags yet.
Team fits the widely supported ‘keep two from Mission 1 and add two new’ plan; no strong red flags yet, and this gives useful information on Bob and Diana even though I’m off the team.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean, I’d like to keep at least two of Alice/Henry/Iris on the next team—probably all three—and add one new person, maybe Bob or Charlie, unless someone has a strong reason to break that core.

I’d rather not lock in all three from the first mission yet—let’s keep two of Alice/Henry/Iris and add two from the rest of us (say, something like Alice, Henry, Bob, Diana) so we get more information without throwing away the Mission 1 data.

I like the idea of keeping two from Alice/Henry/Iris and adding two fresh faces; something like Alice, Henry, Bob, Charlie feels like a good balance of using the clean info we have and widening the net a bit.

I’m on board with the “keep two and add two” approach—something like Alice, Henry, Bob, and me feels like a good way to extend the proven group while actually learning more about the rest of the table.
I’m fine with the “keep two, add two” plan, but I’d lean Alice + Henry as the carry-overs and then Bob + Charlie so we widen the info pool without immediately hard-locking all three from Mission 1.
I like the “keep two, add two” logic, but I’d slightly prefer Alice + Henry plus two from Charlie/Diana/Eve rather than locking in Bob this early, just so we’re spreading the early trust a bit wider.
I’m good with the “keep two, add two” plan, and I’d lean Alice + Henry as the core plus Bob and Diana—that keeps a proven backbone while actually testing a new pair together.

I’m happy to stay with the “keep two, add two” idea using Alice + me as the core, but I’d slightly prefer testing Alice, Henry, Bob, and Charlie so we get reads on two new people who aren’t always auto‑trusted early. If that feels too tight, I’d swap Bob for Diana rather than breaking up the Alice/Henry pair.

I’d like to keep two from the first mission including me—something like Alice, Henry, Iris plus one of Charlie or Diana feels like a good balance between using our one clean data point and not auto-locking Bob this early.

proposals.reasoning: We should anchor on the clean Mission 1 core while fully quarantining everyone from the failed Mission 2 overlap (Bob, Henry, Diana). Alice and Iris come from the only successful mission so far, and literally everyone has been treating them as the provisional good core. Adding myself (Charlie) keeps at least one fresh voice on the mission who has been advocating for the quarantine logic from the start, and including Frank gives us one of the widely town-leaning players who was not on the failed team. This lineup: (1) avoids Bob/Henry/Diana completely to localize the Mission 2 fail, (2) preserves the strongest working core we have, and (3) adds just one additional new player rather than pairing two untested players together, which reduces the chance of accidentally double-stacking evil while still giving us a very informative result.

votes.comment: Quarantines the entire M2 overlap {Bob, Henry, Diana} while keeping the M1 core with me and Iris. From my POV the spy is in {Bob, Henry, Diana}, so Iris is confirmed good. Charlie and Frank are untested but their logic has been pro-quarantine and this team can have at most one overlap spy, making it a solid, informative pick.
Fits the quarantine logic I argued for (benching the Mission 2 overlap while keeping Alice/Iris), and I’m okay with a mostly consensus info-gathering team here.

Solid info team: keeps the M1 core (Alice/Iris), adds Frank (Merlin-lean for me) plus myself, and benches two of the three main M2 suspects (Bob/Diana) while only lightly trusting Alice over Henry. Good balance of safety and information.

I still prefer a fully non-M2-overlap team that matches the earlier consensus more closely—something like Alice, Iris, Eve, Frank—rather than introducing Charlie here when we haven’t seen Eve on a mission yet.

Fits the quarantine plan by excluding all of {Bob, Henry, Diana} from the failed mission while anchoring on Alice/Iris from the clean mission; if this fails, it strongly implicates {Charlie, Frank} and/or reopens suspicion on the supposed core, so it’s both reasonable and informative.
Keeps the Mission 1 core while fully benching everyone from the failed Mission 2 team, which is our cleanest way to localize the earlier fail.

I still want Alice/Iris as the working core, but this feels like an unnecessary deviation from the broadly agreed pool by skipping Eve/Grace and self-including Charlie; I’d prefer a team that better reflects the earlier consensus structure.

Quarantining Bob/Diana is good, but this keeps the potentially evil Alice while swapping in both Charlie and Frank instead of the more broadly supported Alice/Iris/Eve/Frank. Given I know I’m good, the Mission 2 fail points to at least one of {Alice,Bob,Diana} as evil, so I’d rather not add an extra untested (Charlie) on top of a possibly evil Alice when a cleaner alternative exists.

Fits the Mission 1 core logic and benches the main Mission 2 suspects (Bob/Henry/Diana); only real deviation from my earlier preference is Charlie instead of Eve, which isn’t enough to justify stalling here.

discussion.content: From my point of view the fail has to be in {Henry, Bob, Diana}, since I know I’m clean from both missions, so I’d like the next team to be something like me + Iris + two people who weren’t on Mission 2.

Given the clean first mission, I’m inclined to keep Alice and Iris together and pull in two fresh faces like Eve/Frank/Grace, and I’m fine sitting out this one since I was on the failed team. That at least lets us see if the problem was in the overlap (me/Henry/Diana) or not.

I’m happy treating Alice/Iris as a provisional core and would much rather see us bring in people who weren’t on the fail—something like Alice, Iris, Frank, Grace—while we keep Bob/Henry/Diana off this one to narrow down where that Mission 2 fail came from.

I get why people want to bench the whole M2 overlap for info, but I’d actually rather not hard-lock “Alice + Iris” as an unquestioned core yet—something like Alice, Iris, Frank, Eve feels reasonable this round, and then we re‑evaluate how much we trust that pair based on the result.

I like the idea of treating Mission 1 as mostly trustworthy but quarantining the whole M2 overlap for now, so I’d back a team like Alice, Iris, Frank, and me to see if keeping Bob/Henry/Diana off gives us a clean result.

I’m good treating Alice/Iris as a working core for now, and I’d rather see us try something like Alice, Iris, Eve, and me this round so we get a clean read without anyone from the failed team. Between the “new” options, Eve feels a bit safer than Grace to me based on how the discussion’s gone so far.

If we’re quarantining the whole Mission 2 overlap, I’m fine treating Alice/Iris as the working core and pulling from {Eve, Frank, me} for the other two. I’d slightly prefer including me over running both Eve and Frank together so we’re not just locking in the loudest early suggestions as “auto‑good.”

Given the Mission 2 fail, I’m totally fine being benched this round and would back something like Alice, Iris, plus two from Eve/Frank/Grace so we get a clean read without any of the overlap (me/Bob/Diana) muddying things.

I’m on board with treating Mission 1 as our safest anchor for now, so I’d like a team of Alice, me, plus two from {Eve, Frank, Grace}, with a slight lean toward Eve + Frank to fully quarantine the Mission 2 overlap and get the clearest info.

proposals.reasoning: This keeps the widely trusted Mission 3 core of Alice/Charlie/Iris/Frank that already produced a clean success, while avoiding the contentious Mission 2 pair of Bob and Diana that most people read as containing the earlier fail. For the fifth slot, Grace fits the broad preference expressed in discussion: several players wanted an untested addition rather than reusing Henry from the failed pattern, and Grace has drawn less pushback than alternatives. This composition aligns with the emerging table consensus, minimizes reuse of suspicious combinations, and should be broadly acceptable for approval.

votes.comment: Keeps the clean Mission 3 core and avoids the strongly suspicious Bob/Diana from the failed Mission 2; adding a single untested (Grace) feels safer than reusing the Mission 2 pattern.

I still don’t like auto-locking both Iris and Frank off one clean mission and then adding an untested Grace; this feels like we’re treating Mission 3 as solved when it might just have been a no-fail from a hidden evil.
Keeps the clean Mission 3 core and excludes the most suspicious Bob/Diana pair; adding Grace as the untested fifth fits the emerging good-leaning consensus.

This best reflects the emerging consensus to keep the clean Mission 3 core while avoiding the Bob/Diana pair from the failed Mission 2, and adding an untested Grace instead of reusing Henry from the failed pattern looks like a reasonable, low‑risk adjustment.

Best current option: keeps the clean Mission 3 core, avoids the highly suspicious Bob/Diana pair from the failed Mission 2, and only adds one unknown (Grace) rather than reusing anyone from the fail pattern.

I still don’t like locking in both Iris and Frank from one clean mission and then adding a completely untested Grace; I’d prefer swapping Grace for Henry or Eve to reduce the risk of a hidden spy on this critical quest.
Keeps the clean Mission 3 core together, avoids the suspicious Bob/Diana pair from Mission 2, and adds a fresh, untainted slot in Grace instead of reusing the failed pattern.

Keeps the clean Mission 3 core and fully avoids the highly suspicious Bob/Diana pair from the Mission 2 fail; the only real question mark is Grace, which is an acceptable risk compared to reusing the failed patterns.

Keeps the clean Mission 3 core while fully avoiding the suspicious Mission 2 pair (Bob/Diana) and the repeated-pattern risk with Henry; adding a single untested (Grace) is the lowest-risk adjustment from my seat.

discussion.content: Given the clean results, I really want to keep Alice/Iris/Charlie/Frank together and avoid Bob/Diana from the failed mission. For the fifth slot I’d rather add someone untested like Grace than dip back into that Mission 2 pool.

Keeping most of the Mission 3 team is fine, but I don’t think we should auto-clear Iris off a single success—if the fail was on me or Diana in Mission 2, evil had every reason to keep Mission 3 spotless to earn exactly this kind of trust.
I’m very happy locking in the Mission 3 core of Alice / me / Iris / Frank and adding Grace as the fifth, while keeping Bob, Diana, and probably Henry off after that Mission 2 fail pattern.

I agree we shouldn’t just auto-lock the entire Mission 3 team as pure—if Mission 2 had exactly one evil, it’s totally in their interest to keep Mission 3 spotless. I’m fine with Grace as the fifth, but I’d like us to at least re‑evaluate Iris and Frank versus someone like Henry instead of treating that last team as solved.

I like keeping the Mission 3 core mostly intact, but I don’t want to hard-clear all four off one success—if we’re adding Grace, I’d rather see a team like Alice / Charlie / Grace plus two of {Iris, Frank, Henry} than auto-lock Iris *and* Frank together.

I’m pretty comfortable keeping the Mission 3 core together, but I’d rather our “unknown” slot be someone like Henry or Eve than Grace, since piling trust onto a completely untested pick feels a bit rushed here.
I’m happy to go with the Mission 3 core, but I really don’t like auto-locking Iris *and* Frank off one clean result—Alice / Charlie / me plus two from Iris / Frank / Henry feels safer to me.

From my seat the Mission 2 fail almost certainly points at Bob or Diana, so I really want both of them off this team. I’d stick with the Mission 3 core of Alice/Charlie/Iris/Frank and add Grace or Eve as the fifth, and I’m fine staying off to avoid reusing the failed combo.

From my seat the clean Mission 1 and 3 results make Alice/Charlie/Frank plus me the best core, and I really want to keep both Bob and Diana off after that Mission 2 fail. For the fifth, I slightly prefer adding Grace or Eve over re‑using Henry so we don’t recreate any of the failed patterns.

proposals.reasoning: The only fully clean mission with 4+ players is Mission 3 (Alice, Charlie, Iris, Frank). Mission 4 was exactly that core plus Grace and picked up a single fail, so the most direct read is that exactly one of {Frank, Grace} is evil and the Alice/Charlie/Iris trio are very likely good. Mission 1 (Alice, Henry, Iris) was also clean, which reinforces Alice, Henry, and Iris as strong good candidates, while Mission 2 (Alice, Henry, Bob, Diana) failed, indicating exactly one of {Bob, Diana, Henry} is likely evil. To minimize overlap with both failed missions while preserving the strong good core, we: (1) lock in Alice/Charlie/Iris from the clean Mission 3, (2) add Eve as the only player who has never been on a failed team, and (3) choose Henry over Bob/Diana for the last slot to reduce the chance we’re including two suspects from previous fails. This team avoids the Frank/Grace pair implicated by Mission 4’s fail, avoids adding both Bob and Diana from the failed Mission 2, and maximizes reliance on players with multiple clean results (Alice, Iris, Henry) plus the clean Mission 3 structure.

votes.comment: Best use of the Mission 3 core, avoids the Frank/Grace pair implicated by Mission 4, and minimizes overlap with the Mission 2 suspects while keeping multiple players with clean histories.
As evil, I need at least one teammate on the mission to have any chance to win; this team is all likely-good and would lock in a good victory if it succeeds.

Team avoids all main suspect pools from the two failed missions (Bob, Diana, Frank, Grace) while keeping the strongest mechanically cleared core (Alice, Charlie, Iris) plus the only fully clean player (Eve). Henry being the 5th is slightly risky but still the lowest-overlap choice; this is our best odds configuration.

I don’t like double-clearing Henry from both M1 and the logic around M2; this team assumes too strongly that the evil in {Bob, Diana, Henry} isn’t Henry while also giving an untested slot to Eve on the decisive mission.

This uses the strong Mission 3 core (Alice/Charlie/Iris), adds me who’s only been on clean missions, and takes Henry—who has a prior clean with Alice/Iris—over the more suspicious Bob/Diana or the Frank/Grace pair implicated by Mission 4’s fail.
Keeps the clean Alice/Charlie/Iris core, adds the only fully clean player (Eve), and avoids both Bob and Grace from the failed missions, which is about as safe a combo as we can get.

I don’t like how we’re treating Henry as effectively cleared from the Mission 2 fail while also assuming exactly one evil in {Frank, Grace}; that chain of assumptions feels too neat for a final mission, so I’d rather see a team that more explicitly tests the unresolved Bob/Diana/Henry set instead of locking this in.

From my perspective I know I’m good, and Alice/Charlie/Iris look strongly good from the mission pattern. Adding Eve (never on a failed team) and me avoids the Frank/Grace pair and avoids including both Bob and Diana from the failed Mission 2, so this is the lowest-risk composition I can see.

Team fits a consistent world with evils in {B,F,G} and a fully good lineup here; it minimizes overlap with both failed missions and avoids the Frank/Grace pair while using the strongest established core.

discussion.content: Given Mission 3 was clean with Alice/Charlie/Iris/Frank, I think we should start from that core four and add Eve, since she’s the only player who hasn’t touched a failed team yet.

I really don’t like how Mission 4 was just Mission 3 plus Frank and suddenly picked up a fail, so I’d rather treat Frank/Grace as a poisoned pair and go with something like Alice, Charlie, Iris, Eve plus one of Henry or me. That keeps the clean core mostly intact while minimizing overlap with the failed teams.

I’m fine locking in the Alice/Charlie/Iris core and adding Eve, since she’s untouched by any fails so far. Between Frank and Grace I’d only take one (or even consider Henry instead), but I really don’t want both of them on the same team again.

I’m good with locking in Alice/Charlie/Iris plus Eve, and I’d really rather not repeat the Frank/Grace combo after Mission 4. Between the last slot options, I slightly prefer Bob over Henry just because Mission 2 already has that cloud over it.

I like starting from the Mission 3 core but dropping Frank after the Mission 4 fail, so my preferred team is Alice, Charlie, Iris, me, and Henry, since that avoids both the Frank/Grace pair and adding Bob from a known failed team.

I’m comfortable locking in Alice/Charlie/Iris plus Eve, since that keeps us anchored on the clean Mission 3 core while adding someone who hasn’t been on any fails. For the last spot I lean Henry over Bob or repeating the Frank/Grace combo, just to minimize overlap with the two failed missions.

If we’re locking in Alice/Charlie/Iris, I’d rather not just hand a totally “clean” slot to Henry when Mission 2’s info around Bob/Diana is still unresolved; I’d prefer we at least consider one of them over auto-clearing Henry. I’m also fine staying off the team if that helps keep things consistent with the earlier results.

From the mission results, it looks like there’s exactly one evil in {Frank, Grace} and exactly one in {Bob, Diana, Henry}, with Alice/Charlie/Iris very likely good, so I’d rather avoid the Frank/Grace pair and double-dipping on the Mission 2 suspects. I’m on board with Alice/Charlie/Iris plus Eve, and for the fifth I slightly prefer myself over Bob/Diana to keep the overlap with the known fail teams as low as possible.
I’m happy locking in the Alice/Charlie/Iris core with Eve, and for the fifth I lean Henry over Bob or repeating Frank/Grace, just to minimize overlap with both failed missions.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning hardest toward Henry as Merlin. He keeps framing the logic in a way that quietly narrows it down to “Bob or Diana” after Mission 2, then in Mission 5 basically solves the structure as “one evil in {Frank, Grace} and one in {Bob, Diana, Henry}” while still humbly including himself to avoid looking too informed. That level of structured, almost-correct partitioning of the table feels more like someone guiding from hidden info than a normal good trying to guess.

I’m with Bob on Henry being the best Merlin candidate. His Mission 4–5 reasoning keeps softly fencing Bob and me in as the prime suspects while still “offering” himself as possible evil, and that partitioning into {Frank, Grace} and {Bob, Diana, Henry} feels like someone reverse‑engineering the board from near‑perfect knowledge rather than a normal good guessing from noisy data. Alice, Charlie, and Iris all sound like strong, consistent town, but none of them are doing that very specific, careful self-including deduction Henry keeps doing.

I’m mostly with you both that Henry’s the best Merlin candidate: the way he keeps carving the table into those tight partitions — “Bob or Diana” after M2, then “exactly one in {Frank, Grace} and one in {Bob, Diana, Henry}” — is just a bit too structurally accurate for someone who’s genuinely in the dark. Alice and Charlie feel like strong, vocal goods, but their reasoning is more linear and reactive, whereas Henry is consistently steering the narrative while ostentatiously leaving himself in the suspect pool, which is exactly how I’d expect a cautious Merlin to posture.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Henry repeatedly partitions the table in highly structured, near-correct ways—first soft-fencing the blame to Bob/Diana after Mission 2, then later deducing there is exactly one evil in {Frank, Grace} and one in {Bob, Diana, Henry} while still including himself to avoid looking too certain. That pattern of accurate global reasoning, paired with deliberate self-inclusion in suspect pools, fits a cautious Merlin more than a normal uninformed good player.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on teams that ended up being mostly trustworthy and avoided drawing Merlin-like attention, which helped protect Frank during the assassin phase. I could improve by being more vocal in challenging suspicious team comps after Mission 2’s fail and by more actively pushing alternative theories about who Merlin might be to misdirect the assassin.

player_observations.Bob: Took advantage of Mission 2 to slip in a single fail, playing cautiously enough to avoid immediate hard suspicion but never fully rebuilt trust afterward.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very protective role around Frank, consistently supporting teams with him while still maintaining enough ambiguity to keep Merlin’s identity somewhat obscured.
player_observations.Diana: Used her leadership on Mission 4 to insert herself into a failing team, blending in with a mix of trusted and semi-trusted players to make the source of the fail ambiguous.
player_observations.Eve: As a good player and final mission leader, she built a team that leaned heavily on previously successful patterns, showing a preference for data-driven, low-risk choices.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he steered teams subtly, backing good-heavy compositions without over-defending anyone, which helped him stay just outside the assassin’s crosshairs.
player_observations.Grace: Played Morgana by mirroring some of Merlin-like behavior, supporting mixed teams and occasionally aligning with Frank to muddy the information trail for the assassin.
player_observations.Henry: Despite being good, his presence on the failing Mission 2 and the winning Mission 5 made him a plausible assassin target, suggesting he played in a way that was neither overly cautious nor overly vocal.
player_observations.Iris: Stayed on multiple successful teams and maintained a relatively low profile, which made her appear reliably good without attracting much strategic attention from evil or the assassin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well engineering the fail on Mission 2 in a way that didn’t immediately lock me in as evil and helped sow some doubt. However, my Merlin read was off, and I tunneled too much on Henry instead of re-evaluating after Mission 4’s fail and Frank’s consistently safe team selections. Next time I should track who’s subtly steering correct teams rather than just who looks ‘too clean.’

player_observations.Alice: Consistently included a strong core of good players and avoided raising suspicion, which suggests a naturally low-key and logical style. You tend to favor stable, repeat-team compositions once they’ve succeeded.
player_observations.Charlie: Very protective of information and seemed to quietly guide team choices, fitting Percival well. You’re assertive in backing certain players without over-explaining, which can make you persuasive but hard to read as good or evil.
player_observations.Diana: You played Mordred subtly, taking just enough risk (like being on the failing Mission 2 team) without drawing a spotlight. Your evil playstyle leans toward blending in with the logical majority rather than forcing aggressive pushes.
player_observations.Eve: You came across cautious and somewhat conservative in voting, not trying to drive table narrative too hard. That made you look reliably good but not ‘loudly good,’ which helped you avoid the Merlin crosshairs.
player_observations.Frank: You were very measured: you supported the right teams and avoided dramatic speeches, which was excellent Merlin camouflage. Your influence was felt more in quiet agreement and nudges than in overt leadership, which fooled me.
player_observations.Grace: You played Morgana with a pretty restrained style, not over-claiming information or loudly mimicking Merlin, which reduced suspicion on you. Your votes were usually aligned with what looked reasonable, supporting a subtle-evil approach.
player_observations.Henry: Your play felt straightforward and honest, and you didn’t try to over-justify your decisions, which read as very genuine. That ‘clean’ image actually drew my assassin shot, so your natural transparency can accidentally look like hidden information.
player_observations.Iris: You played very stably, approving solid-looking teams and not overreacting to fails. Your low-drama style helped establish trust around you and contributed to good having a reliable presence on multiple missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Percival, I correctly maintained strong town-cred while consistently pushing to keep Frank on teams and subtly defending him from assassination without over-clearing him too loudly. I could improve by more aggressively questioning Diana and Grace after Mission 2’s fail and by more clearly seeding doubt on Henry as a likely safe but non-Merlin target to mislead the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and ended up as a frequent anchor pick for teams; your low-drama, steady style made you look reliably villagery all game. You could perhaps push your reads more explicitly so evils have to react to you rather than quietly riding along.
player_observations.Bob: You blended into early missions reasonably well and only caused one fail, which kept suspicion spread out. However, your positioning after the failed Mission 2 didn’t strongly redirect heat, which made it easier for good to narrow down evil later.
player_observations.Diana: You were a fairly persuasive leader and got an important fail through on Mission 4, showing good timing in when to sabotage. That said, your overall voting and team preferences started to form a pattern that tied you to other suspicious players, which made you more readable in hindsight.
player_observations.Eve: You played a cautious but generally pro-good game, and your Mission 5 leadership was solid in locking in a winning team. At times you seemed to follow consensus more than drive it, which kept you safe but also limited your impact on shaping earlier missions.
player_observations.Frank: You balanced information and caution very well as Merlin, nudging teams toward good configurations without being too obvious. There were a couple of moments where your support for certain teams (like Mission 3) almost looked too clean, but overall you disguised your role convincingly enough to dodge the assassination.
player_observations.Grace: You had a flexible, adaptive style and did a good job mirroring good-player reasoning, especially around midgame. Over time, though, your attempts to subtly steer teams away from fully clean configurations created slight inconsistencies that became noticeable when missions were compared in sequence.
player_observations.Henry: You looked quite suspicious after appearing on the failed Mission 2 and then again on the final team, which made you a natural mis-assassination target. Your willingness to stay engaged and argue your innocence, though, helped keep the game dynamic and made evil’s final read more difficult.
player_observations.Iris: You had a very towny presence with straightforward, logic-based voting and team feedback, which made it easy for good to trust you on key missions. If anything, you might have been almost too clean and agreeable, giving evil fewer chances to make visible mistakes under pressure from you.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably with the evil team by helping secure a fail on Mission 4 without drawing too much direct blame there, and I stayed out of the spotlight enough that I was never strongly suspected as a power role. However, I could have done more to subtly steer suspicions toward Frank earlier, and I should have more actively framed Henry or another good player as likely Merlin to give the assassin a clearer, safer target.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very steady, low-flash game—repeatedly trusted on teams and used that social capital well without over-arguing, which made her feel like a default-safe choice for many leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Leaned into flexible voting and team choices that kept suspicion spread out, but didn’t quite create a compelling Merlin candidate, which made the final assassination more of a guess than a deduction.
player_observations.Charlie: Very vocal and directional, clearly trying to guide team selection and reads—fit the Percival profile well by strongly backing Iris and Frank in a way that seemed like informed but not omniscient trust.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and tended to follow the emerging consensus, which made her look reliably good but not like a power role—her Mission 5 leadership was conservative and trust-based.
player_observations.Frank: Did an excellent job as Merlin by being influential without being too loud—he nudged people toward broadly good-leaning teams (like on Missions 1 and 3) while leaving just enough ambiguity to avoid being cleanly identified.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she injected doubt and alternative narratives at key points but didn’t fully become the ‘obvious Merlin candidate’; her mid-game positioning created some confusion but not enough to pull heat fully off Frank.
player_observations.Henry: Came off as solid but not central—often treated as a safe filler pick on teams and didn’t push super strong theories, which made him a plausible but not screamingly obvious assassination candidate.
player_observations.Iris: Consistently read as very trustworthy due to being on two successful missions and arguing in a calm, reasoned way; she projected a ‘clean villager’ aura that helped anchor good-leaning team formations.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my voting and helped push through a strong final team, which contributed directly to the win. I could have been more vocal in sharing structured reasoning and reads earlier, which might have put additional pressure on the evil team and made the final missions less tense.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be trusted early due to being on multiple successful missions, and maintained a stable, low-drama presence that made her look reliably good.
player_observations.Bob: Played a subtle evil game by blending into early discussion and taking a calculated risk on Mission 2, but didn’t generate quite enough towncred to avoid late suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as methodical and reasoning-focused, consistently trying to frame missions and votes in a logical way that fit well with a Percival mindset.
player_observations.Diana: Used her leader position to push a mixed team that looked plausible, balancing aggression with just enough caution to keep herself from seeming blatantly evil.
player_observations.Frank: Did an excellent job as Merlin by guiding team selections toward good-heavy lineups without overexplaining, staying helpful but not so accurate as to be obviously targetable.
player_observations.Grace: Leaned into a confident and slightly assertive style that fit Morgana well, creating ambiguity around information and making it harder to cleanly separate her from Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very natural, low-key good game; his inclusion on both a failed and a successful team made him a believable but ultimately misleading assassination target.
player_observations.Iris: Looked consistently good by being on key successful missions and keeping a cooperative, non-flashy profile that didn’t attract much suspicion or assassination pressure.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I balanced giving useful guidance with staying hidden well enough that the assassin missed me, especially around Missions 3 and 5 where I could subtly steer toward mostly-good teams. I could improve by planting a bit more doubt on Diana and Grace earlier without overly clearing Henry, since he ended up looking like a more obvious Merlin candidate than I intended.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently ‘good’ and was frequently included, which helped stabilize team cores but also made it easier for evil to hide around her.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, blended in reasonably well, but the single fail on Mission 2 made him look suspicious to attentive players since that team had otherwise strong good candidates.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, did a good job trusting the right information overall and repeatedly anchoring teams around me and Iris, though occasionally could have pressed harder on the Diana/Grace axis.
player_observations.Diana: As Mordred, played a low-key but effective sabotage role, slipping in one fail at a time and avoiding overly loud pushes that might have drawn attention.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as cautious but logical, and her leadership on Mission 5 showed a willingness to commit to a read once enough evidence had built up.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, sold herself well as a potential Merlin/percival-adjacent good, but the timing and composition of the failed Mission 4 ended up putting subtle pressure on her position.
player_observations.Henry: Looked like a plausible Merlin to evil due to participating in both an early fail and the final success, and his generally thoughtful table talk made him a natural target for the assassin.
player_observations.Iris: Consistently read as very good, especially after clean results on Missions 1 and 3, and her repeated inclusion on successful teams helped form a reliable core for good.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I created enough Merlin confusion that Henry became a plausible target, but I didn’t lean hard enough into plays that would make Frank look risky without clearing him entirely. I also could have coordinated better with Bob and Diana on when to fail and when to pass, especially around Mission 4, to set up a stronger, more credible Merlin candidate for the final guess.

player_observations.Alice: Very consistently trusted and frequently on teams, she played a solid, low-flash good game that made her feel like a default-safe pick for most leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Took the fail on Mission 2 in a way that didn’t draw too much heat, but also didn’t fully capitalize on that info later to shape stronger suspicions toward a different Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he did a good job of keeping both Merlin candidates viable in public discussion and subtly steering teams toward the real Merlin without over-justifying it.
player_observations.Diana: Her Mordred play stayed relatively quiet and under-the-radar, blending in well, though she could sometimes have pushed harder to redirect suspicion at key moments.
player_observations.Eve: Played a straightforward, trustworthy good role and was willing to be on important late-game teams without over-arguing, which helped her look stable and unthreatening.
player_observations.Frank: Played an excellent low-key Merlin, providing just enough guidance to keep teams mostly clean while never sounding like he had special information.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a believable Merlin candidate by being vocal enough and occasionally wrong, which made him a reasonable but ultimately incorrect assassination target.
player_observations.Iris: Appeared consistently cooperative and non-controversial, often included on successful teams and not generating much suspicion, which helped good maintain reliable mission cores.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in team votes and helped anchor trust on Alice and Iris, which paid off in Mission 1 and the final team. I could have been more vocal in connecting the pattern of failed missions to Diana and Bob sooner, and I might have drawn a bit more suspicion onto myself to help protect Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Very steady and generally trusted; her early inclusion on multiple teams built a strong core of perceived-good players that shaped most later team compositions.
player_observations.Bob: Played the assassin role aggressively but subtly, using the single fail on Mission 2 to create doubt without over-exposing himself; tried to sit in a semi-trust zone rather than appearing too clean.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into the Percival role by strongly backing Frank and often aligning with Iris, pushing a specific narrative of who was trustworthy without over-explaining their reads.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to get on key missions as Mordred, especially Mission 4, and used that fail to create chaos while not loudly directing suspicion, relying more on positioning than open argument.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very straightforward good style; her leadership on Mission 5 was decisive and she was willing to trust the established core instead of overthinking late-game possibilities.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, gave clear but not overly obvious guidance, subtly steering teams away from the worst evil combinations while avoiding hard accusations that would reveal his role.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, mirrored Merlin-like confidence at times to muddy the waters for Percival, often chiming in with plausible reads that supported evil-aligned team constructions.
player_observations.Iris: Consistently appeared clean and cooperative; her presence on successful missions and measured table talk made her an anchor for good, especially in justifying the final team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-town in my voting and mission behavior, which helped me avoid suspicion and kept me included on most critical teams. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and doing a better job of pushing structured reads earlier, instead of mostly following the emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Often trusted early and played a very stable, low-drama good role that made her a frequent anchor pick for teams.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, blended in fairly well but felt a bit opportunistic in team preferences, especially around the failed Mission 2.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a confident, guiding role as Percival, frequently steering team selection and subtly protecting who he thought was Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: As Mordred, she was calm and controlled, pushing teams in ways that created just enough doubt without becoming the main suspect.
player_observations.Eve: Played straightforwardly and seemed to base decisions heavily on previous mission results, which made her look logically consistent and trustworthy.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he was very measured—nudging team compositions in the right direction without overexplaining, which helped avoid the assassination.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she projected a strong, Merlin-like confidence at times, creating real ambiguity around who held information.
player_observations.Henry: Generally read as quiet but cooperative good; his inclusion on multiple teams without causing fails helped reinforce his towny image despite the final assassination guess on him.
